statement.tex: %text If the lines $\dfrac{x-1}{-3}=\dfrac{y-2}{1}=\dfrac{z-3}{2}$ and $\dfrac{x-1}{k}=\dfrac{y-2}{1}=\dfrac{z-3}{5}$ are perpendicular, find the value of $k$ and hence find the equation of plane containing these lines. %

step.context: L_1:\dfrac{x-1}{-3}=\dfrac{y-2}{-2k}=\dfrac{z-3}{2} \\ L_2:\dfrac{x-1}{k}=\dfrac{y-2}{1}=\dfrac{z-3}{5} \\ %text If $L_1\perp L_2$, what is the value of $k$? %
step.reason: %text If the angle between two lines is $\theta$, then % \cos\theta=\left\vert\dfrac{a_1a_2+b_1b_2+c_1c_2} {\sqrt{a_1^2+b_1^2+c_1^2}\sqrt{a_2^2+b_2^2+c_2^2}}\right\vert \\ %text where $a_1$, $b_1$, $c_1$ and $a_2$, $b_2$, $c_2$ are respectively the direction ratios of the two lines. Since $L_1\perp L_2$ therefore, % \begin{align} &(-3)(k)+(-2k)(1)+(2)(5)=0 \\ \implies &-3k-2k+10=0 \implies k=2 \end{align}

step.context: L_1:\dfrac{x-1}{-3}=\dfrac{y-2}{-4}=\dfrac{z-3}{2} \\ L_2:\dfrac{x-1}{2}=\dfrac{y-2}{1}=\dfrac{z-3}{5} \\ %text What are the vector equations of the above lines $L_1$ and $L_2$? %
step.reason: %text For a line passing through $(x_1, y_1, z_1)$ and having direction ratios $a$, $b$ and $c$, the vector and cartesian equations are: % \qquad\begin{align} &\dfrac{x-x_1}{a}=\dfrac{y-y_1}{b}=\dfrac{z-z_1}{c} \\ &\ora{r}=\vector{x_}{y_1}{z_1}+\lambda(\vector{a}{b}{c}) \end{align}

step.context: L_1: \ora{r}=\vector{1}{2}{3}+\lambda(\vector{-3}{-4}{2}) \\ L_2: \ora{r}=\vector{1}{2}{3}+\lambda(\vector{2}{1}{5}) \\ %text The normal to the plane containing above two lines would be? %

%text Since $(\vector{1}{2}{3})$, is a point common to both lines and the plane containing them, and the normal to the plane is given by $\vector{-22}{19}{5}$, what is the equation of the plane containing the lines? %
step.reason: %text If $\ora{r}$ is the position vector of any point on the plane, $\vector{1}{2}{3}$, is a point on the plane and $\vector{-22}{19}{5}$ is the normal to the plane then, % \begin{align} &(\ora{r}-(\vector{1}{2}{3}))\cdot (\vector{-22}{19}{5})=0 \\ &\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{-22}{19}{5})= \\ &\qquad\qquad(\vector{1}{2}{3})\cdot(\vector{-22}{19}{5}) \\ &\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{-22}{19}{5})=31 \end{align} \\ %text In cartesian form this would be, % \begin{align} (\vector{x}{y}{z})\cdot(\vector{-22}{19}{5})&=31 \\ -22x+19y+5z&=31 \end{align}
